field.label: 1.1. Assign Attribute to Variable
field.comment:
Assign product attribute code to a variable that will be used in custom math formula.

Attribute type supported: Text Field

Mapping format: attribute_code=>your_variable_name;

Example:
weight=>w;
color=>c;
size=>s;
...

NOTE: We suggest one mapping per line for readability. Terminate each line with semi-colon. Use only lower-case letters for variable names and _underscores if you need to break up multiple words.

field.label: 1.2. Assign Option Title to Variable
1.3. Assign Non-option Variable
1.4. Assign Special Values
1.5. Variable Init Values
field.comment:
Deprecated. This option will be removed soon. Non-option variables (1.3) can be used instead.

Set the init value for options that do not exist in some products so the global price logic defined here in the admin area can be used on many products even though not all products have the same options. The perimeter option is used to ensure math is correct when using perimeter based calculations - should be set to zero so that perimeter calculations are not off by 1 on init calculations.

Mapping format: your_variable_name=>value;

Example:
depth=>1;
depth_perimeter=>0;
glass_price=>0;
license=>0;
license_price=>0;
...

field.label: 1.6. Unit Option Labels
field.comment:
List product custom option title(s) that are used to offer different measurement units to customer on the product page. Semi-colon separated list when more than one option title used.

Option types supported: Drop-down, Radio Button

Example:
Measurements unit; How did you Measure?

field.label: 1.7. Default Radix
field.comment:
Input the calculation square unit (width and height).

Example:
Enter 1 when both are the same unit
Enter 0.01 when width and height are in cm , but square unit is m

field.label: 1.8. Min Input Setting
field.comment:
List of variables from 1.2 with their respective minimum acceptable numeric input value. Use the variable name only with no curly brackets around it.

Mapping format: your_variable_name=>value;

Example:
width=>5;
height=>8;
...

NOTE: We suggest one mapping per line for readability. Terminate each line with semi-colon. Make sure your variable text matches exactly the value from 1.2 and be sure to NOT use curly {...} brackets around the variable name here.

field.label: 1.9. Max Input Setting
field.comment:
List of variables from 1.2 with their respective maximum acceptable numeric input value. Use the variable name only with no curly brackets around it.

Mapping format: your_variable_name=>value;

Example:
width=>200;
height=>400;
...

NOTE: We suggest one mapping per line for readability. Terminate each line with semi-colon. Make sure your variable text matches exactly the value from 1.2 and be sure to NOT use curly {...} brackets around the variable name here.

field.label: 1.10. Min Input Validation < min
field.comment: Example:  Min {title} = {min} {unit}

field.label: 1.11. Max Input Validation > max
field.comment: Example:  Max {title} = {max} {unit}

field.label: 1.12. Custom Validation and Alert
field.comment:
Semi-colon separated list of custom validation logic. At least one variable must be mapped from an option title to show the message on the product page.

Mapping format: Conditional formula :: Message;

Example:
({width} > 50) && ({height} > 50) :: Only one value may be > 50 cm;
({height}/{width}) > 5 :: Height has to be smaller or equal to 5 times width;

NOTE: We suggest one mapping per line for readability. Terminate each line with semi-colon.

field.label: 1.13. Remove Custom Price
field.comment:
Use the Remove Custom price config if you use the {var_price} in your calculation logic, it will eliminate a duplicate option price issue. Magento will also calculate a price when you assign one to any custom option, this tells it to be ignored. List of variables from 1.2. Use the variable name only with no curly brackets around it.

Example:
finish;
color;
frame;

NOTE: We suggest one mapping per line for readability. Terminate each line with semi-colon. Make sure your variable text matches exactly the value from 1.2 and be sure to NOT use curly {...} brackets around the variable name here.

field.label: 1.14. Update Quantity Instead of Price
field.comment: Change quantity on the product page and keep original price.

field.label: 1.15. Enable Customer Group
field.comment: Customer group name will be used in logic using the {customergroup} variable.

field.label: 1.16. Use Special Value Options
field.comment:
Some custom option values should use the special value set in 1.4 after price calculations are complete, e.g. table range pricing based on a range of values.

Mapping format: variable_name=>variable_name;

Example:
discount_one=>discount;
sq_price=>sq_price;

NOTE: We suggest one mapping per line for readability. Terminate each line with semi-colon. Make sure your variable text matches exactly the value from 1.2, 1.3 or 1.4 and be sure to NOT use curly {...} brackets around the variable name here.

field.label: 1.17. Relation Value Setting
field.comment:
Some custom option values should be set automatically by another value.

Option types supported: Text Field

Mapping format: variable_name=>variable_name

Example:
width=>{height} * 1.5;
height=>{width} / 1.5;

NOTE: 1.3 Non-option variables are not supported at this time.

field.label: 1.18. Show Total Price At Product Page
field.comment:
Yes : Show Total Price.
No : Show Unit Price.

field.label: 1.19. Keep Global Special Values
field.comment:
Yes : Keep Global Special Values.
No : Use only override Values.

group.label: 2. Custom Math and Logic Setting
group.comment:
Reference Index

Reserved Variable names 
{customergroup}
   The customer group customer is assigned to 
{newprice}
   The current price in calcuation 
{price}
   Product base price 
{weight}
   Product weight 
{qty}
   Product quantity
Variables Explained     
{var}
   Holds the value of the variable 
{var_price}
   Holds the value of the option price defined at product 
_price
   Call the option value price 
_perimeter
   Perimeter value to ensure accuracy for perimeter addition 
_default
   Default is when variable is not set, but product has it. Useful to set {var_default} value when doing multiplication calculations so price does not zero out until another specific option gets set. 
_{customerGroupName}
   Lowercase customer group name to target specific customer group conditions. To be used only with the {customergroup} reserved variable. E.g. Retailer customer group can be mapped {customergroup}_{retailer}=>2; 
Variable init value config
   For options not in all products (global use case)
Calculation Operators 
 *Â 
   Multiplication 
+
   Addition 
-
   Subtraction 
/
   Division 
%
   Modulo 
( )
   Order of operation
Comparison Operators 
>
   Greater than 
<
   Less than 
==
   Equals 
>=
   Greater than or Equal to 
<=
   Less than or equal to 
!=
   Not equal 
!
   Logical Not 
||
   Logical Or 
&&
   Logical And
Conditional Operators 
?:
   (Advanced) The ternary operator is used for conditional logic.
Usage: (expr1) ? (expr2) : (expr3);
The expression (expr1) ? (expr2) : (expr3) evaluates to expr2 if expr1 is TRUE or expr3 if expr1 is FALSE. "Stacking" ternary expressions is supported but make sure to wrap the respective branches within (parenthesis). Stacking too many expressions within too many parenthesis may cause unexplainable results.
Simple Functions 
abs
   Returns the absolute value of number or variable. Usage: abs({var}) 
ceil
   Returns the next highest integer value by rounding up value if necessary. E.g. 4.1 and 4.01 will ceil to 5. Usage: ceil({var}) 
floor
   Returns the next lowest integer value by rounding down value if necessary. E.g. 4.9 and 4.01 will floor to 4. Usage: floor({var}) 
round
   Returns the rounded value of val to nearest whole number. E.g. 3.4 and 3.499 rounds to 3, 3.5 and 3.519 rounds to 4. Usage: round({var})

field.label: 2.1. Price Logic
field.comment:
A global price calculation formula can be set here and it can be overriden per product.

Example:
{width} * {height} * {price} + ({width} + {height}) * {glass_price}

Supported variables: {price} and any {var} defined in 1.1, 1.2, 1.3 (Reference)
Supported operators: Calculation (Reference)
Supported functions: abs, ceil, floor, round

field.label: 2.2. Unit Conversion
field.comment:
Conversion mapping for different radix options.

Example:
m=>{val}*1;
cm=>{val}*0.01;
mm=>{val}*0.001;
inches=>{val}*0.0254;

Supported operators: Calculation (Reference)

NOTE: We suggest one mapping per line for readability. Terminate each line with semi-colon.

field.label: 2.3. Variables That Use Unit Conversion
field.comment:
Semi-colon separated list of variables.

Example:
width;height;

NOTE: Leave 2.3 empty to convert all variables with unit conversion math.

field.label: 2.4. Subtract Qty Logic
field.comment:
Used to subtract quantity from inventory. Does not check actual qty when adding product to cart.

Example:
{width} * {height} * {qty}

Supported variables: {price}, {qty}, and any {var} defined in 1.1, 1.2, 1.3 (Reference)
Supported operators: Calculation, Comparison and Conditional (Reference)
Supported functions: abs, ceil, floor, round

field.label: 2.5. Weight Logic
field.comment:
Example:  {width} * {height} * {weight}

Supported variables: {price}, {qty}, and any {var} defined in 1.1, 1.2, 1.3 (Reference)
Supported operators: Calculation, Comparison and Conditional (Reference)
Supported functions: abs, ceil, floor, round

field.label: 2.6. Upcharge Logic
field.comment:
Example:
({width} + {height} >= 1) && ({width} + {height} <= 10) :: -0.15 * {width} * {height} * {price} ;
({width} == 5) && ({height} == 10) :: 0.15 * {width} * {height} * {price};

Format explanation:
{math of expression one} :: {math of price one} ; {math of expression two} :: {math of price two} ;

Supported variables: Reserved + any {var} defined in 1.1, 1.2, 1.3 (Reference)
Supported operators: Calculation, Comparison and Conditional (Reference)
Supported functions: abs, ceil, floor, round

field.label: 2.9. Create Attributes
field.comment:
Use this checkbox to create the necessary attributes for per-product overrides. Make sure you save config settings at least once before using this checkbox. Read instructions below.

How to use the auto create attribute checkbox:
1. Copy the example mapping values from 2.7 helper-text into the text-area provided in 2.7
2. Select the attribute set(s) you want the attributes to be created in
3. Click [Save Config] button at top of the page
3. After config saved, return here to 2.9 and check the Create Attributes checkbox
4. Click [Save Config] button at top of the page
5. Done!
